question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Compute
\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^{2016}.\]
inference:
**SOLUTION**
Given
\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^{2016},\]
note that
\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^{2016}=\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^{4\cdot 504}\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^{0}\]
$$=\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^{4\cdot 504}\begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix}$$
$$=\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^{4\cdot 504} .$$
Now
\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^{4}=\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}\]
$$=\begin{pmatrix} 9 & -12 \\ 3 & -4 \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} 9 & -12 \\ 3 & -4 \end{pmatrix}$$
$$=\begin{pmatrix} 81 & -108 \\ 27 & -36 \end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix} 9 & -12 \\ 3 & -4 \end{pmatrix}$$
$$=\begin{pmatrix} 729 & -972 \\ 243 & -324 \end{pmatrix}$$
$$=\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^{4}.$$
So,
\[\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^{2016}=\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^{4\cdot 504}\]
$$=\left(\begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}^{4}\right)^{504}$$
$$=\begin{pmatrix} 729 & -972 \\ 243 & -324 \end{pmatrix}^{504}.$$
Hence, the answer is
$$\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 729 & -972 \\ 243 & -324 \end{pmatrix}.}$$

**Final Answer: \boxed{$\begin{pmatrix} 729 & -972 \\ 243 & -324 \end{pmatrix}$}. I hope it is correct.**
ground_truth:
Let $\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix}.$  Note that
\begin{align*}
\mathbf{A}^2 &= \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \begin{pmatrix} 5 & -8 \\ 2 & -3 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= 2 \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} -  \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= 2 \mathbf{A} - \mathbf{I}.
\end{align*}Thus, let
\[\mathbf{B} = \mathbf{A} - \mathbf{I} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & -4 \\ 1 & -1 \end{pmatrix} - \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -4 \\ 1 & -2 \end{pmatrix}.\]Then $\mathbf{B}^2 = \mathbf{0},$ and $\mathbf{A} = \mathbf{B} + \mathbf{I},$ so by the Binomial Theorem,
\begin{align*}
\mathbf{A}^{2016} &= (\mathbf{B} + \mathbf{I})^{2016} \\
&= \mathbf{B}^{2016} + \binom{2016}{1} \mathbf{B}^{2015} + \binom{2016}{2} \mathbf{B}^{2014} + \dots + \binom{2016}{2014} \mathbf{B}^2 + \binom{2016}{2015} \mathbf{B} + \mathbf{I} \\
&= 2016 \mathbf{B} + \mathbf{I} \\
&= 2016 \begin{pmatrix} 2 & -4 \\ 1 & -2 \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} \\
&= \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 4033 & -8064 \\ 2016 & -4031 \end{pmatrix}}.
\end{align*}Note: We can expand $(\mathbf{B} + \mathbf{I})^{2016}$ using the Binomial Theorem because the matrices $\mathbf{B}$ and $\mathbf{I}$ commute, i.e. $\mathbf{B} \mathbf{I} = \mathbf{I} \mathbf{B}.$  In general, expanding a power of $\mathbf{A} + \mathbf{B}$ is difficult.  For example,
\[(\mathbf{A} + \mathbf{B})^2 = \mathbf{A}^2 + \mathbf{A} \mathbf{B} + \mathbf{B} \mathbf{A} + \mathbf{B}^2,\]and without knowing more about $\mathbf{A}$ and $\mathbf{B},$ this cannot be simplified.
